WORLD BANK Staff Working Paper No. 380 April 1980 WOMEN IN THE URBAN LABOR MARKETS OF AFRICA: THE CASE OF TANZANIA The low status of women in the modern sector in Africa has been commented on by many authors but very few studies have sought to explain the reasons for the disparity in employment opportunities in the modern sector between men and women in Africa. This study seeks to fill the gap in the literature by using the results of the 1971 Tanzanian National Urban Mobility, Employment and Income Survey (NUMEIST) to focus specifically on urban women and their labor market performance. The study examines the structure and characteristics of the female urban labor force, the determinants of female employment and labor earnings and attempts to ascertain whether sex differ- ences in labor market performance can be attributed to sex discrimination. Apart from the constraints arising out of the general economic situation in the country, factors that emerge as important determinants of female employment status are: marital status, nature of female dependence on the husband and educational attainment. The analysis of differentials in labor earnings indicatesthat, while African urban women may not suffer appreciably from sex discrimination, either in terms of wage level or as a result of occupational segregation, the urban women's low economic status in the labor force is primarily a result of cumulative discrimination over time in both the provision of and the demand for educational services. This has had the effect of limiting the supply of women in the urban labor force and making the female labor supply curve less elastic than that of men. The paper discusses some policy options that governments may wish to adopt to remedy the situation.  CHAPTER 1 INTRODUCTION and SUMMARY 1.1 Objective Despite considerable literature on urbanization and the problems associated with surplus urban labor in Africa, few attempts have been made to study the process of urbanization of women and the performance of women in the urban labor market. It may be argued that urban problems of under util- ization and their principal forms, under-employment and unemployment, are shared by men and women and that policy prescriptions arising out of research on unemployment as it affects men are also applicable to women, but many of the problems women encounter in the urban economy and the labor market are sex specific. Some of these problems are associated with their life cycle commitments, while others arise because of the low status of women in society. A man at the end of his educational training is expected to enter the labor force and to remain there, assuming that there are jobs available, until retirement; a woman's entry into the labor force is conditioned by her plans relating to marriage and childbearing, as well as by the social expectations of what role she should assume in society. In Africa, although society expects her to enter the labor market, she is still expected to fulfill her role relating to procreation and family responsibilities. While labor market conditions in the rural sector may make it possible for a woman to pursue dual careers (and most African women do so), conditions in the urban areas are less conducive than in rural areas to the combination of home and market activities. Furthermore, in the urban environment, where the necessity for a woman to work is even more pressing for some families owing to the husband's low income and increased family wants, women have more severe problems in adjusting to unfamiliar life styles.
 Urbanization is a fairly recent phenomenon in Africa and most urban dwellers are first generation or recent immigrants. The inability to draw on the support of the wider extended family so readily available in the rural areas affects women more intensely than men. The low status of women in the modern sector in Africa has been commented on, but very few studies have sought to explain the reasons for the disparity in employment opportunities in the modern sector between men and women. This study seeks to fill the gap in the literature by focusing specifically on urban African women and their labor market performance. A subsidiary but important reason for a study focusing specifically on urban women is the importance of female employment as a means of providing women with an alternative source of satisfaction to that derived from having children. In high-fertility African countries, where female status derives almost entirely from the motherhood role, many women feel compelled to have as many children as possible. Research results indicate that modern sector employment can offer women viable partial alternatives to marriage and motherhood. Thus, studies which seek to shed light on the employment status of women in urban areas of Africa should be useful to policy makers. The objectives of this study therefore are to ascertain the char- acteristics of the women in the urban labor market and to compare the labor market performance of men and women in the urban economy. Some of the ques- tions we hope to address are: Are there sex differentials in employment status and earnings? If differentials exist, to what factors can they be attributed? Are they explained by differences in education and job train- ing, or are they even a result of discrimination? And finally, what steps might be taken to close the gap between the sexes and help further integrate women into the urban economy?
 -3- 1.2 Data Source As a principal source of information, Tanzania has been selected for this study because there are fairly good household data on employment and income in the urban areas. The 1971 National Urban, Mobility, Employ- ment and Income Survey (NUMEIST) provides a rich source of data suitable for an analysis of this type. The survey covered 5,000 persons from seven urban centers in Tanzania. These are: Dar es Salaam, Arusha, Mwanza, Tanga, Tabora, Dodoma and Mbeya. The sample selection and enumeration procedures are described by Sabot. 1/ The other reason for concentrating on Tanzania is that in the Arusha Declaration, 1967, the Tanzania Government committed itself to a policy of sexual equality and has since taken considerable steps to ensure that both urban and rural women benefit from this policy. This study is not restricted to Tanzania, but has tried where possible to include information from other African countries. While it can be said that each country's position is fairly unique, we feel confident that the analysis and the conclusions of this study are applicable to the majority of sub-Saharan African countries. 1.3 Chapter Summary Previous studies have shown that rural-urban migration in Africa has been predominantly male and until fairly recently there has been very little female migration into urban areas of sub-Saharan Africa. In the past, given the short-term nature of male urban migration, it was most unusual for wives to accompany husbands to town. However, in the post-second world war period, there was a sharp increase in the size of the female 1/ R. Sabot: Economic Development and Urban Migration, A Study of Tanzania. Clarendon Press 1978.

Since the increase cannot be explained by the natural rate of increase alone, it indicates a shift in the pattern of female migration. Chapter 2 discusses the reasons for this phenomenon. There was a shift in male migra- tion patterns from short-term to long-term during this period. Consequently, the move to the city involved whole families instead of just the male member as in the past. During the post-war period, the rate of male migration into urban areas increased sharply, owing to increased economic opportunities in the modern sector. Since the rate of female migration derives to a large extent from male migration, it was inevitable that this would have an effect on the rate of entry of female urban migrants. Although the proportion of female migrants who came as economic dependents remained high, the rate of migration of unattached females grew at a much higher rate than that of married females, indicating that women migrants were also responding to the same economic motives for migrating as the men. A factor contributing to this was education. During the 1960s, there was a net increase in the number of women in educational institutions in Africa. Given the educational selectivity of the migration process in Africa, it was not surprising that the process should also affect women. To the educated woman, the urban economy offered the probability of employment towards which school curricula have been directed, as well as the oppor- tunity for upward social mobility. Given the high female labor-force participation in rural Africa and the numerical importance of women in the urban population (50% of urban work age population are women), Chapter 3 examines the structure and char- acteristics of the female urban labor force. It begins with an analysis
 of its socio-economic characteristics. The important point to emerge is that although women make up approximately 50% of the urban work age popula- tion, there are very few women in the formal sector of the urban economy, where educational attainment is a pre-requisite. Using the broadest defini- tion of employment, we find that in Tanzania, approximately 21% of the urban women are employed compared with 80% of the men. The majority of women urban labor force participants are in job situations not very different from that of rural women. An examination of the occupational distribution of women indicates the beginning of a pattern of concentration of women in few occupa- tions similar to the pattern in developed countries, although the pattern has yet to become as pronounced as in Kenya. Chapter 4 examines the determinants of female employment in Africa. Apart from constraints arising out of the general economic situation in the country, factors that emerge as important determinants are marital status and the nature of female dependence on the husband, the presence of children and educational attainment. The chapter hypothesizes that education by itself cannot ensure access to employment, but that the chances of being employed are greatly improved by the nature and length of a woman's on-the-job experience, especially in a tight labor market situation. Finally, a labor supply func- tion using household survey data from urban Tanzania was estimated. The results of empirical analysis confirm the importance of wage, education and household status as determinants of labor force participation. Moreover, education is an important factor in determining whether or not a woman finds employment in the formal sector. Given the wide differentials in earnings and labor force status of men and women in urban Africa, Chapter 5 examines the determinants of
 - 6 - labor earnings and attempts to ascertain whether sex differences in labor market performance can be attributed to sex discrimination. Important reasons for differential earnings are women's low level of human capital and skills which preclude them from high-level jobs with high remuneration. The preponderance of women in the informal sector of the urban labor market can be explained by the fact that education is not a prerequisite for entry into employment in this sector. However, since high remuneration in this sector is dependent on capital outlay and many women lack this, their prospects of earning high incomes are severely limited. The empirical estimation of the earnings function confirms that women do not suffer from sex discrimination, but that labor income is highly correlated with educational attainment. This leads to a discussion of the reasons for African women's comparatively low educational attainment vis-a-vis that of African men. The conclusion from the evidence presented is that, while there may not be sex discrimination in urban Africa either in terms of wage level or occupational segregation, women's low status in the labor force is a result of cumulative discrimination over time in both the provision of and the demand for educational services. This has had the effect of limiting the supply of women in the labor force and making the female labor supply curve less elastic than that of men. Supply differences between men and women are determined by family decisions and have been reinforced by Government action. Expansion of female skilled labor has been prevented by discrimina- tory practices of fathers who do not give their daughters access to education similar to that of their sons and by the governments who do not provide sufficient training facilities to women. Chapter 6 contains the policy implications.
 - 7 - Policy suggestions that have emerged from this study are as follows: (1) Girls should be provided with more access to education by making all schools coeducational and ensuring that the school intake reflects the ratio of the sexes in the population and also that girls are not automatically put into an inferior educational stream which would not give them a chance of competing in high status and high income jobs. (2) Major efforts should be made to expand and modify the adult education system, so that the current illiterate, underemployed and poor urban women may have an oppor- tunity of upgrading their skills and ability and thereby increasing their income. (3) The educational system should also be restructured so that provision is made for the school dropouts and older people to re-enter the system and obtain education which would improve their earning potential.

Almost 49% came from rural areas. 2.2 Urbanization of Women Until fairly recently, migration from one area to another in Africa has been predominantly male. Given the historical evolution of towns and cities this is not surprising. Urban areas in Africa had their raisons d'etre as centers of communication and collecting points for locally produced goods or through development of minerals. The incentives to provide labor in such centers were specifically directed at the men. 2/ The norm was for the men to migrate to sell their labor while the women stayed behind to tend the family plots and care for the children. Living conditions in such centers of migration did not encourage migration of whole families. Before the Second World War, therefore, given the short term nature of migration, it was relatively uncommon for women to accompany their husbands, although a certain number of widows, deserted wives and other unattached women went with the men. The situation in Tanzania is illustrative of other areas in Africa experiencing rapid social change. An important contribution of this section is that it attempts to extend the analysis for developed countries to Africa. We begin by presenting the basic model of labor supply based on the individual utility maximization and discussing the conceptual issues arising from it when applied to the African urban market. The empirical model for this study is presented and the choice of the variables discussed. The results of analysis are then presented and discussed. Participation in the labor force involves a decision by the indi- vidual on how to allocate his/her time and a decision on the part of the employer to offer the individual a job. It is this interaction of supply and demand that determines whether or not a person participates in the labor force. In empirical estimation of labor supply, it is not always possible to specify the demand schedule, especially when the analysis is confined to the household level because information on labor demand variables is usually lacking. On a macro-level, with aggregate data from a well defined labor
 - 77 - market, the average wage rate facing the individual worker is observable and is exogenous to the potential worker, whereas when the data are at a disaggregated level, there is usually no information available on the labor market and, therefore, no information on the wage rate facing the individual worker. Given this, therefore, it is normal to restrict the analysis to the supply conditions, as we do here. The labor force status equation estimated below is derived from a simple model of individual behavior in which the individual is assumed to maximize his/her utility subject to an income constraint. The individual utility function proposed is simple and contains only two arguments: the individual's leisure time, L, and the amount of composite goods G consumed. Ignoring the tax rate on income and goods, and making the assumption that the wage rate is exogenous, the microeconomic problem faced by the individual is to maximize the following utility function U(L, G), subject to the following constraint: (T - L)w + y - PG = 0 where w = hourly or monthly wage rate. y = unearned income: the income flow that would accrue if the individual does not work at all. P = the price of G. T = length of time period. Since L = T - H where H = number of hours in the labor market. The use of an individual utility function in the estimation of the labor supply function of a woman is not the standard acceptable procedure. The accepted framework is to estimate the labor supply function within the family utility maximizing framework. The argument is that the individual's use of time between market and non-market activity can best be understood within the context of the family, since there is interdependence of needs

Within this framework, the amount of time a woman de- votes to market work is viewed as being dependent on the effective wage of the spouse as well as the non-labor income of the family. The assumption here is that men's work consists exclusively of paid time in the market and a large portion of a woman's time is devoted to unpaid non-market work which even though it commands no monetary price is still of immense economic value to the family. In this study we have not used family income as a determinant of a woman's time allocation between home and market work because the concept is inappropriate for Africa. Since women's func- tions are traditionally related to tasks concerning the family, care of children and older relatives, provision of food and house maintenance, pur- chasing and selling food, women invariably choose careers in the modern sector associated with those traditional tasks--petty trading, small farm cultivation, house maids, serving in restaurants, nursing, etc. In all Africa, therefore, social expectations of what is to be regarded as a proper female role influence decisions regarding occupations by those women who seek a role other than that of wife and mother. Within the monopsonistic framework developed here, separation of the labor market by sex implies wage discrimination against women only if their labor supply to the firm is less elastic than that of the males. No study has yet been done to measure the degree of elasticity of female or male labor supply curves in Africa in response to wage rate changes. The ideal way of finding this out would be to measure empirically changes in employment by sex which result from changes in wages offered by firms. Wage and employment data for most African countries are not available on a firm-by-firm basis. But a priori evidence exists to support the view that the individual female supply curve is less elastic than that of the male, given the fact that in the male market, the competition for male labor is between employers whereas for female labor, the employer also competeq for
 - 121 - time with the demands on women's time imposed by life cycle responsibili- ties. The implicit value of time devoted to home activities may make the labor supply curve for women upward sloping whereas for men, the oppor- tunity cost is constant and the labor supply curve may be horizontal for the individual. 1/ Another reason for this may be that men in Africa generally have more employment opportunities--including those requiring brute force and no education--whereas women have more restricted employment opportunities. Less direct evidence can be obtained by looking at the labor market for skilled personnel. Entry requirements in jobs with skill unlike the unskilled jobs require some type of formal education. Both the Kenyan and Tanzanian Governments admit to having acted in a discriminatory manner towards the delivery of educational services to their female populations. Considering the disparities in education between men and women in the educational delivery system, the Manpower Report to the Tanzanian President 1974/75 suggests that taking into account the number of girls in secondary schools, it seems that they have fewer number of available places in schools than boys. The report goes on to suggest that consideration should be given to converting some of the boys' secondary schools into coeducational schools so as to increase the proportion of girls. The Kenyan Government is already attempting to institute changes in the form of more coeducational facilities, and more girls' secondary schools, and this should help to reduce the inequality considerably. 2/ There is also a proposal to increase training facilities for women in specific female-oriented occupational programs. This 1/ J. F. Madden op. cit. 2/ N.C.O.E.P. report on Educational Objectives: Nairobi 1977.
 - 122 - should have the effect of increasing the number of women in these occupations. The government hopes that its policy of universal primary education will in time lead to an increase in the number of girls in secondary schools. This can only happen if the government would embark on a policy of unisex secondary education. Given the government's intended policy of restricting expansion of secondary education on the whole, an abolition of the present single sex secondary school system would be one method of giving those girls who now have access to primary education an equal chance of access to secondary level education. The 1974 Manpower Report to the President of Tanzania reported that there were fewer facilities for girls' education than those for boys. Of the 80 public secondary schools, only 18 were solely for girls while 44 were boys' schools and the remaining 18 were coeducational. There were 10 private girls secondary schools compared with 21 boys' schools and 26 co-educational. With the situation being what it is, it is not surprising that the enrollment of girls has been maintained at the same ratio since 1961. Even in 1974, girls represented 32% and 14% of all Form One and Form Six children respectively. In spite of being a socialist economy, the general educational system is organized in such a way that only 50% of the children between 7-14 get primary education. Of those who completed the 7 year education, only 10% went on to the next level which is a college preparatory level. The university intake from this group is about 60%. If, for lack of facilities, few women have the opportunity to enter the second level of education, it follows that only a very tiny minority of them will obtain the type of training which would ensure entry into high-income occupations.
 - 123 - In contrast with the coeducational character of primary schools in Kenya, most aided secondary schools are single sex. "The distribution of places in aided secondary schools which provide at lower cost higher quality schooling than unaided schools shape the educational opportunities at this stage of schooling...." In 1968 there were 143 aided schools for boys and 61 for girls, and 28 mixed institutions. By 1977, these numbers had risen to 200 aided boys schools and 107 girls schools and 65 coeduca- tional schools. 1/ The number of streams in aided schools also favors the boys. (In 1977, there were 377 streams in secondary schools for boys, 184 in girls schools and 96 in mixed schools.) The distribution confers a 2:1 advantage on boys. The above statistics do not reflect the extent of sex typing prevalent in the educational system, which further curtails the range of options accessible to Kenyan women who pursue secondary and vocational training. For example, women are effectively excluded from government tech- nical and vocational secondary schools because of accommodation difficulties since such schools are normally for boarders. Although a clear test of elasticity of labor supply by sex is not possible currently due to lack of data, evidence exists to support the hypo- thesis that in Africa, the female labor supply curve is less elastic than the male one. This can be proven by the fact that expansion of female skilled labor has been prevented by discriminatory practices by the government relat- ing to provision of training facilities to women, and by fathers who do not give their daughters access to education similar to that of their sons. 1/ C.B.S.: Women in Kenya: Social Perspectives, Vol. 3, No. 2, April 1978.
 - 124 - 5.5 Summarv Summing up, therefore, we can say that, given the data we have, the analysis has indicated that in Tanzania, length of schooling, length of time on the job and acquisition of marketable skills are the most important influences on earnings from employment. Since women are on the whole less skilled, less experienced and less educated, these facts reflect the income differences between them and men. Although the empirical analysis indicates that there is no wage discrimination by sex in the urban labor market, evidence presented here supports our central thesis that, apart from differ- ences in earnings due to differences in productivity associated with human capital, it is possible in African urban labor markets for differences in earnings from labor to be associated with sex discrimination resulting from the dominance of the male market power in the urban economy, insofar as men through their political power have restricted the supply of female labor. The poor performance of women in the labor market and their low earning profile is a result of cumulative discrimination over time in the delivery of educational services. For both men and women, the most important determinant of labor income is education. In the past, fathers have denied daughters access to education but even now that parental prejudice have to some extent been overcome, the Governments have not provided women equal access to educational services. By restricting the intake of women into the higher levels of educational strata, the Governments are in effect depriving women of an important means of raising their standard of living and thereby reinforcing their low status in society.
 - 125 - CHAPTER 6 POLICY IMPLICATIONS One of the important facts that has emerged from this study is that women in urban Africa are the most disadvantaged group. The study has demonstrated that although women make up over 50% or thereabouts of the urban population, their labor market contributions are restricted to the unstructured sector of the labor market requiring no training or skills and therefore lower earning capacity. In the modern sector, there are relatively few women, simply because these jobs require in most cases some form of educational training. Furthermore, on average, women earn less than men with the same educational qualifications. Some of the reasons for disparity in earning can be attributed to job classifications and to the relative lack of on-the-job experience by women, since they are in effect the last group to enter the modern sector employment. The most important reason for the low status of women and their disadvantaged position in the economy is their lack of education. In the 1974 Tanzanian Annual Manpower report to the President, the view was expressed that at secondary level, female enrollment ratios have remained virtually at 1961 levels. In 1961-1974 only a quarter of the state public school places were occupied by girls. While the proportion is slightly higher in the lower rung of the secondary schools, 1/ it falls off markedly in the upper forms. Between 1961-1974, the Ministry of National Education in its annual report indicated that the proportion of females enrolled in 1/ IBRD: Tanzania Credit 149-8A, Second Education Project Completion Report, April 1977, p. 23.

The position has improved considerably above what it was in 1971 when the survey was conducted but it is still a situation of con- siderable concern. The situation is not very different in other African countries. Everywhere, there has been an increase in the number of girls in primary schools in recent years but the proportion of girls in secondary schools has not improved at all. President Nyerere 1/ has stressed the socialist conception of the equality of all human beings and the fact that, for Tanzania to make full and quick progress, women must be accorded equal opportunity with men. Policy statements 2/ from Tanzania indicate the aim of promoting equal access of women to education and training opportunities at all levels so as to provide them access to better work and earning opportunities. The report of the Government of Tanzania to the East African consultative group meeting recently 3/ specifically stated as a government objective increasing enrollment for girls in secondary schools so as to give them opportunity for contributing to national development and to enable every illiterate Tanzanian woman to become literate. The policy statements appear to be mere rhetoric when one compares them with the actual practice in many countries. Improvements in female educational performance and their subsequent integration into the modern sector are constrained by the fact that women are in a culture which accords them very low status and which by implication makes them wards of the men who are in positions of authority both in the family and in the government. In some instances, parental attitude to education of girls is reinforced by the fact that education does not necessarily improve the marketability of the educated in the marriage market. The expectation that girls should help with household responsibilities interferes with their attendance at school. The teachers in the schools tend, like teachers elsewhere, to devote more time and attention to those pupils who have the most chance of reaching the highest possible position. This inferior position reinforces itself and the girls invariably think that they are only suited for certain types of educa- tion simply because they have no role models. In many girls' schools, the tendency has been to channel girls automatically into female subjects and the teachers themselves are unable to give those girls who wish to pursue differ- ent subjects any encouragement. Recently, Mbilinyi 1/ has expressed concern about the curriculum choices offered to girls and the implications of the system of streaming for 1/ M.  - 128 - their future prospects. The same concern has been expressed in Kenya by the report of the National Commission on Educational Objectives and Policies in Kenya. At the primary level in all African countries, all subjects are taken by all the pupils irrespective of sex. Entry into secondary schools is based on examination. The drop-out rate of the girls at each stage is very high and cannot be explained by lower intellectual capability than that of boys. Apparently, the subject combinations for students at secondary level where the instruction is in English are determined by the vocational bias of the particular school. (Domestic science, commerce, agriculture, crafts and technical subjects). The streaming of students in the schools depends on teachers' recommendation based on their perception of the student ability and performance in classroom. Subject combinations are determined by the stream in which the student is placed and this in turn determines the future education and occupational choices. If, as is usually the case, a girl enters into the commerce stream, her chances of taking science or eventually going on to post-secondary level education is virtually nil. 1/ Given the explicit relationship in the Tanzanian case between manpower requirements and educational opportunities, post primary education is invariably the prerequisite for obtaining wage employment and increasing one's earning power even at the informal labor market. In order that girls should be given equal access to education and training, it is essential that they should also be given the opportunity to realize their full potentiality by ensuring that not only are enough places provided for them at schools but that they are given 1/ M. Mbilinyi, op cit. This situation applies to all sub-Saharan African countries.
 - 129 - freedom to pursue whatever subject they wish to undertake. The Tanzanian Government as well as the Kenyan Government in their statemnts have often expressed the intention of increasing the number of girl's schools, but what is required is a policy of making all schools coeducational and ensuring that a set number of places is given to girls in accordance with their number in the population. Most African governments fully realize the need to tie educational opportunities to job opportunities. If girls are given equal access to educa- tion with boys at all levels of educational streams, the current imbalance in modern sector employment between the sexes may disappear within a generation. However, the policy of creation of more places at schools for girls will only affect the current and future school-age population of most countries. As the survey indicated, there are currently in the urban areas of Tanzania a large number of illiterate women or women who have had one or two years of schooling. This situation is not different in other African countries. These women have no prospect of modern sector jobs, and are underemployed and have incomes below the poverty level. Many of these women are heads of households with financial responsibilities to their families which they are not able to meet. Adult education classes in most countries in the past have concentrated on literacy classes. While this is not neces- sarily bad in-so-far as it provides the participants with a means of func- tioning in a world where understanding the written word is important, it does not really provide the participants with the opportunity to acquire skills and training which would help them raise their standard of living. One way out of this is to restructure adult education classes so that, in addition to their current literacy training role, the classes can be used as a means of
 - 130 - upgrading skills and teaching the underemployed, underutilized women better ways of utilizing the resources available in the country to meet the basic needs of themselves and their families. Such training does not require too much financial investment. It may just in some instances necessitate informal training in better accounting procedures so that petty traders can distinguish between capital and current income or it may be training on better storage facilities for crops so as to protect them from pests. -Another aspect of the educational system which militates against African women is the lack of opportunity to re-enter the educational system when one has dropped out either because of financial reasons or because of an unplanned pregnancy. This is a universal problem. This means that a girl who is unable to complete primary or secondary school level education has no way of pursuing her educational career even if she so desired in the future. Older persons of either sex are also unable under the current system to re-enter the system for their own self-improvement. There have been dis- cussions with UN/ECA regarding the participation of Tanzania in a project to study the problem of female early school leavers and identify ways of meeting their needs, particularly for training to assist them in income gen- erating activities. This project, if it materializes, will undoubtedly assist the girls who have been expelled from school on account of pregnancy. However, it is suggested that the Governments should give serious considera- tion to restructuring the educational system, so that those whose education has been terminated for whatever reason can re-enter the system and have the opportunity of completing their educational, training.
 - 131 - Policy suggestions that have emerged from this study are as follows: (1) Girls should be provided with more access to education by making all schools coeducational, ensuring that the school intake reflects the ratio of the sexes in the population, and ensuring that girls are not automatically put into the inferior educational stream which would not give them a chance of competing in high status and high income jobs. (2) Major efforts should be made to expand and modify the adult education system to provide the current illiterate, underemployed and poor urban women an opportunity of upgrading their skills and ability to increase their income. (3) The educational system should be restructured so that provision is made for the school dropouts and older people to re-enter the system to obtain education which would improve their earning potentiality.

doc.repnme: Women in the urban labor markets of Africa : the case of Tanzania
doc.abstracts: This study examines the structure and characteristics of the female urban labor force, the determinants of female employment and labor earnings and attempts to ascertain whether sex differences in labor market performance can be attributed to sex discrimination. Apart from the constraints arising out of the general economic situation in the country, factors that emerge as important determinants of female employment status are: marital status, nature of female dependence on the husband and educational attainment. The analysis of differentials in labor earnings indicates that, while African urban women may not suffer appreciably from sex discrimination, either in terms of wage level or as a result of occupational segregation, the urban women's low economic status in the labor force is primarily a result of cumulative discrimination over time in both the provision of and the demand for educational services. This has had the effect of limiting the supply of women in the urban labor force and making the female labor supply curve less elastic than that of men. The paper discusses some policy options that governments may wish to adopt to remedy the situation.
